page.title: 11ROYAL OAK COTTAGE
page.content: This 2-storey house stands near the south end of the main street in {Horton Kirby.}It dates from the early 1600's and is built of brick around a wooden frame. The walls rest upon a flint base, and there is no damp course. The name of the cottage derives from its former use as a public-house. No spirits were sold: it was exclusively an ale-house. Boys had to sit on a bench in the porch to drink their lemonade. The building fell into such disrepair that it was condemned just before the Second World War. In 1946, following a grant for restoration, the cottage was first reduced to its original timber structure, and then entirely rebuilt. An extension cons- isting of a kitchen and bathroom was later added to the rear of the house.
